page.title: 13DERBYSHIRE HILL FARMING 1.
page.content: A typical Derbyshire hill farm rears calves for meat and sheep for both meat and wool. At one local farm, the hardy Gritstone sheep live out during the winter months with extra feed during bad weather. Most of the flock lamb in April or May, although a few are brought in early to lamb. Shearing is done in mid-June, when the fleece must be completely dry. It is compulsory to dip sheep twice each year, in August and October, against scab and other skin pests. Some of the lambs and older ewes are sold at the end of August at local markets e.g. Bakewell and Hartington. The native Gritstone sheep are bred for their good quality fleece and for meat, whilst a Swaledale/Suffolk cross is bred mainly for its meat. See{PAGE 14}for other farm activities.
